etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French comparer, from Latin comparare, from compar ‘like, equal’, from com- ‘with’ + par ‘equal’

notes.text: Traditionally, compare to is used when similarities are noted in dissimilar things: shall I compare thee to a summer's day? To compare with is to look for either differences or similarities, usually in similar things: compare the candidate's claims with his actual performance. In practice, however, this distinction is rarely maintained. See also contrast

definitions: estimate, measure, or note the similarity or dissimilarity between

examples.text: individual schools compared their facilities with those of others in the area
the survey compares prices in different countries
total attendance figures were 28,000, compared to 40,000 at last year's event

definitions: point out the resemblances to; liken to

examples.text: her novel was compared to the work of Daniel Defoe

definitions: draw an analogy between one thing and (another) for the purposes of explanation or clarification

examples.text: he compared the religions to different paths toward the peak of the same mountain

shortDefinitions: draw analogy between one thing and another

definitions: have a specified relationship with another thing or person in terms of nature or quality

examples.text: salaries compare favorably with those of other professions

shortDefinitions: have specified level of similarity to

synonyms.text: be in the same class as
be in the same league as

definitions: be of an equal or similar nature or quality

examples.text: sales were modest and cannot compare with the glory days of 1989

synonyms.text: be in the same class as
be in the same league as

definitions: form the comparative and superlative degrees of (an adjective or an adverb)

examples.text: words of one syllable are usually compared by “-er” and “-est.”

shortDefinitions: form comparative and superlative degrees of word
